title: Can AI Coach an Athlete? My Two-Week Touch Rugby Training Plan
text:
Introduction




My Touch Team!!


Touch rugby is one of those sports most people in the United States have never heard of, but the rest of the world absolutely loves. It is especially big in Australia and New Zealand, where people grow up playing it the way kids here grow up playing basketball or soccer. The easiest way to describe it is that it is a version of rugby without tackling. Instead of getting taken to the ground, play stops with a simple touch. Think of it as tag with a ball, except everyone is sprinting, passing, stepping, and trying to outsmart each other at full speed. It looks simple until you try it, and then you realize how technical and exhausting it actually is.
In two weeks, I will be attending a three-day touch rugby training camp as part of my preparation for USA Nationals with the NYC team. The camp runs from eight in the morning to four in the afternoon and each day is packed with drills, attacking lines, defensive patterns, footwork, conditioning, sprint work, and constant ball handling. It will be the most intense stretch of touch rugby training I have done so far, and I want to make sure I am actually ready for it.
Two weeks is not a lot of time to prepare, and I did not want to show up to camp feeling unprepared. So instead of randomly picking workouts or hoping practices would be enough, I asked an LLM to help me create an actual training plan. I wanted something realistic that matched the speed, movement, and ball-handling demands of touch rugby. This post includes the prompt I used, the plan the AI created, and my first impressions before I try it out.

Prompt:

I have a three-day touch rugby camp in two weeks. Each day runs from eight in the morning to four in the afternoon with constant movement including drills, sprinting, defensive structures, attacking lines, gameplay, agility work, conditioning, footwork, and ball handling. Please design a training plan to help me get ready. Include a realistic two-week training schedule, specific conditioning workouts for agility, sprint speed, and endurance, strength preparation focused on core stability, lower-body strength, and injury prevention, daily recovery recommendations, nutrition and hydration guidance for long training days, and mental preparation strategies that support confidence, game awareness, and fast decision-making. Make the plan tailored to the demands of touch rugby specifically.



Response:

Absolutely! Preparing effectively for a three-day touch rugby camp requires a smart, well-rounded two-week plan that targets the physical, mental, and tactical demands of the sport. Below, you‚Äôll find a tailored 14-day approach focused on:

Training Schedule Overview

Detailed Conditioning Workouts

Strength & Stability Training

Recovery & Mobility

Nutrition & Hydration

Mental Preparation & Tactical Awareness

OR do:

End with 2 laps of field jog + dynamic stretching

üëü Final 3 Days Before Camp

‚ú® Summary of Priorities

You‚Äôll show up faster, sharper, more resilient‚Äîand most importantly‚Äîmentally ready to perform across all three days. Good luck with camp‚Äîdominate it! üèâüî•

title: Can AI Coach an Athlete? My Two-Week Touch Rugby Training Plan
text:
Reflection
Even though I already know how to train for touch rugby, it was still interesting to see how the AI organized everything. The plan felt structured and sport specific, and it brought together elements I already focus on, like sprint work, agility, ball handling, endurance, and recovery, but in a different format than I usually create for myself. It did not teach me anything completely new, but it did lay everything out in a way that made the next two weeks feel more intentional and easy to follow.
I was surprised that the AI did not ask me any follow-up questions about my schedule, my current level of athleticism, or whether I had any injuries. A real coach would have asked those things immediately, so the lack of personalization made the response feel less human and more template-based. Even so, some of the workouts were genuinely interesting and more creative than what I would have come up with on my own. It reminded me that AI can give strong starting points, even if it cannot fully tailor a program the way a live coach could.
Overall, I can see myself using this kind of plan again for inspiration or structure, especially when I am short on time or want ideas for specific types of drills. It is not a replacement for a touch coach, but it is definitely a useful tool for staying organized, motivated, and a little more creative with training.

title: Color Me AI
text:
Introduction

Colors have always felt like a quiet way of describing people. Some remind you of bright mornings, others of soft, muted evenings. Each shade carries emotion and energy in its own way. I wanted to see if AI could capture that by looking at me.
I sent ChatGPT a photo of myself and asked it to create a five-color palette based on what it saw. I wanted to know what colors it would choose to represent me and whether any of them would actually feel right.


Prompt:

Imagine the energy I give off in this photo as a color palette. I am the one on the right. Create five colors that capture my aura and personality, not my clothing or background. Include hex codes and describe what each color represents.






Response:

üåü Aura Color Palette: ‚ÄúSkyline Spark‚Äù


1. Electric Confidence ‚Äì #FF7E6B
A vibrant coral-pink tone that feels bold, charismatic, and approachable. This represents your outgoing nature and the energy you effortlessly bring into a room. You radiate warmth and friendliness without overpowering anyone.


2. Citylight Grit ‚Äì #2C2A4A
A deep midnight indigo, capturing your ambition, intelligence, and urban elegance. Like the city skyline behind you, you seem rooted and unshakably self-assured while still striving skyward.


3. Sunlit Joy ‚Äì #FFE68A
A soft golden-yellow symbolizing your inner joy, spontaneity, and glow. You seem like someone who helps others feel brighter just by being around.


4. Cool Horizon ‚Äì #A5D4EF
This airy sky blue captures your sense of clarity, calm confidence, and openness to the world. You‚Äôre driven yet relaxed, focused yet fun‚Äîa refreshing presence like a clear view from a rooftop.


5. Empowered Chic ‚Äì #A25CFF
A bold lavender-lilac hue with a touch of mystery and creativity. This reflects your stylish individuality, adaptable spirit, and the electric charisma that makes you stand out in any social space.



üé® My Aura Color Palette


















Electric Confidence ‚Ä¢ Citylight Grit ‚Ä¢ Sunlit Joy ‚Ä¢ Cool Horizon ‚Ä¢ Empowered Chic

title: Color Me AI
text:
Reflection
ChatGPT‚Äôs response showed how easily color can be used to describe personality. Each shade came with a small narrative that linked mood to visual tone, almost like painting with words. It was interesting to see how language can shape how we imagine color and how those choices can suggest emotion or energy without directly saying it.
This experiment made me think more about how we read people visually. We often connect certain colors with certain feelings, even without noticing it. The AI just put that process into words.

title: Can AI Do Halloween Better Than Me?
text:
Introduction:
Halloween and I have a long history of doing the absolute minimum. Most years I panic grab something from my closet and hope no one notices I put in zero effort. But since it is my senior year, I wanted to at least try a little harder. Not full Pinterest dedication, just better than usual. My goal was to reuse as much as possible from my closet while still looking cute, fun, and a little creative.
Instead of spending hours scrolling or overthinking it, I decided to let an LLM choose my Halloween costume for me. I wanted to see if AI could actually understand my vibe and give me ideas I would genuinely wear. Nothing expensive, nothing uncomfortable, just realistic options that match my style. I was not sure if it would be helpful or chaotic, but it made the whole decision feel more fun and a lot less stressful.

title: Can AI Do Halloween Better Than Me?
text:
Prompt:

I need help choosing my Halloween costume this year. I am a college senior and I want to try a little harder than usual while still using as much as I can from my own closet. I want something cute, fun, and creative but still realistic and comfortable to wear. Ask me three short questions first to understand my style, personality, comfort level, and what I might already own. After I answer, give me at least five costume ideas that genuinely fit my vibe. Explain why each idea matches me and how easy it would be to put together with common clothes and accessories.


Getting To Know My Style:

ASSISTANT: Okay, I can help you brainstorm some costume ideas that fit your style. Answer these three quick questions.

Describe your everyday style in three words. What colors do you usually wear
On a scale from 1 to 5, how much effort are you willing to put into a costume, and are you okay with simple makeup or props
Is there a theme, aesthetic, or show you have been drawn to lately You can keep it general

I will give you personalized ideas after your answers.


USER:

comfy, trying to be trendy, mostly neutrals like black, white, grey, navy
normally a three, but for Halloween a four
anything cute and recognizable, nothing anime

title: Can AI Do Halloween Better Than Me?
text:
Final Costume Reveals:

ASSISTANT: Here are five costume ideas that match what you told me. Each one uses your closet, fits your color palette, and is cute and recognizable.


1. Modern Wednesday Addams
Why it fits you: The black and white color palette matches your everyday style, and it is cute, trendy, and very recognizable.
How to make it: A black dress layered over a collared shirt, black tights, boots, simple braids, dark eyeliner.


2. Chic Vampire
Why it fits you: Works perfectly with your dark neutrals and gives you an elegant, cute, and slightly dramatic Halloween look.
How to make it: All black outfit, dark lipstick, simple fangs, optional fake blood.


3. Audrey Hepburn in Breakfast at Tiffany‚Äôs
Why it fits you: A timeless, classy costume that looks like you put in effort without being uncomfortable.
How to make it: Black dress, black flats or heels, pearls, sunglasses, hair up.


4. Modern Mime Artist
Why it fits you: Black and white aesthetic, cozy, creative, and instantly recognizable.
How to make it: Striped or plain shirt, black pants or skirt, light makeup with bold eyeliner, optional beret.


5. Taylor Swift Reputation Era
Why it fits you: Cute, trendy, and exactly your color palette. Recognizable without being over the top.
How to make it: All black outfit, dark makeup, boots, and snake-themed accessories.

title: Can AI Do Halloween Better Than Me?
text:
Reflection:
Trying this experiment actually ended up being more helpful than I expected. I thought the AI would give me random or over-the-top ideas, but the suggestions were surprisingly on point. What made me laugh a little was how many of the characters it mentioned were ones I had already brainstormed myself at some point. Wednesday Addams, Audrey Hepburn, a cute vampire moment, even Reputation era Taylor Swift all fit the exact color palette I wear every day. It made me feel like the AI actually understood my style better than I expected.
I also appreciated that all the ideas were realistic and comfortable, which is exactly what I wanted. Nothing felt dramatic or out of character for me. Everything was cute, recognizable, and easy to build from pieces I already own. It felt like the AI filtered my entire closet and personality into a small list of options that made total sense.
Overall, I was pleasantly surprised by how well this worked. It made the whole process feel more fun and way less stressful, and it reminded me that my everyday style already leans toward a lot of Halloween-adjacent looks. I would definitely use AI again for costume brainstorming, especially when I want something low effort but still cute.

title: A Brief History of Intelligence: First Impressions
text:
Reflection:
I just started A Brief History of Intelligence by Max Bennett, and the opening chapters set a thoughtful foundation for the rest of the book. Bennett begins by outlining the scope of his project, which is to explain how intelligence emerged across species and how those biological developments relate to modern artificial intelligence. His tone is clear and deliberate, and he writes in a way that feels accessible without oversimplifying the science. It is obvious he intends this book to bridge ideas from neuroscience, evolution, and computational modeling.
The early chapters focus on the large question of what intelligence actually is, and why understanding its origins matters. Bennett frames intelligence as a layered, cumulative process that evolved over millions of years rather than something that appeared suddenly. I appreciated how he situates humans not as a separate category, but as part of a long continuum of life that gradually developed increasingly complex cognitive abilities. This perspective feels grounding and aligns well with what I have learned in my neuroscience coursework.
Another thing that stood out is the way Bennett positions artificial intelligence within this evolutionary context. He hints that AI systems do not emerge from biological pressures, yet they borrow patterns from evolution, such as incremental refinement, feedback loops, and the accumulation of complexity. Even in these early chapters, he draws subtle parallels between biological intelligence and modern machine learning architectures. It made me think more carefully about the boundaries between natural and artificial forms of intelligence.
The opening chapters were surprisingly easy to follow, and they left me interested in where Bennett is going next. I‚Äôm curious to see how he expands these early ideas and how he connects the biological story of intelligence with the rapid changes happening in AI. It already feels like a book that will make me rethink how I understand intelligence as a whole.

title: I Let an LLM Coach Me Through a Mini Crisis
text:
This fall, I took the train to NYC to help my friend after she got a concussion. I wasn‚Äôt panicking, but I also wasn‚Äôt completely sure what ‚Äúconcussion care‚Äù actually looks like outside of a lecture slide. I‚Äôve sat through enough neuroscience classes to know the basics, but applying that in a real moment felt different.
So I opened an LLM and asked it how to take care of her in the simplest, most practical way. I wanted to see whether an AI model could be grounding and helpful when someone I cared about needed me to show up, not academically but personally.

title: I Let an LLM Coach Me Through a Mini Crisis
text:
Prompt:

My friend just got a concussion and I‚Äôm taking care of her for the weekend. I want to make sure I‚Äôm doing the right things, but I‚Äôm not completely sure what actual concussion care looks like outside of what I‚Äôve learned in class.


Please give me clear, practical guidance on: what I should do
what I should avoid
what warning signs I should watch for
how to support her physically and emotionally while she recovers


Keep it simple and tell me what matters most in the first 24‚Äì48 hours.

title: I Let an LLM Coach Me Through a Mini Crisis
text:
Response:

You‚Äôre doing a great thing by taking care of your friend. Concussions are brain injuries, and the first 24‚Äì48 hours are important for monitoring symptoms and giving the brain time to begin healing. Here‚Äôs a clear, simple guide to help you:


üü¢ What You Should Do:



Let Her Rest



Encourage physical and mental rest. No physical activity, no schoolwork, no video games, or texting.
Keep things quiet and calm.


Monitor Her Closely



Stay nearby so you can check in regularly. You don‚Äôt need to wake her up constantly if she‚Äôs sleeping unless her doctor said to.
Check her every few hours: Can she speak clearly? Does she know where she is? Does she respond normally?


Offer Light, Easy Foods



Only if she feels okay to eat. Avoid anything too heavy if she feels nauseated.


Help Limit Screens



Keep TV, phones, tablets, and computers off or to an absolute minimum. They can make symptoms worse.


Help Her Stay Hydrated



Offer small amounts of water regularly.


Keep Notes



Write down any symptoms you notice and if they change or worsen. This helps if you need to talk to a doctor.



üõë What to Avoid:

No physical activity or sports
No driving, biking, or operating anything
No alcohol or medications (unless prescribed for the concussion)
No loud music, bright lights, or screen time
No tough mental tasks (homework, intense conversations, etc.)



üö® Warning Signs ‚Äî Call a Doctor or 911 If You Notice:

Repeated vomiting
Loss of consciousness (even briefly)
Increasing confusion, agitation, or unusual behavior
Slurred speech, weakness, or numbness
Seizure activity (shaking, convulsing)
One pupil larger than the other or uneven eye movement
Trouble walking or staying awake



üíõ How to Support Her Physically and Emotionally:

Be patient and reassuring. She might feel frustrated, slow, or tired ‚Äî that‚Äôs normal.
Keep the environment calm. Dim lights, low noise, low stress.
Let her know it‚Äôs okay not to ‚Äúbounce back‚Äù right away ‚Äî recovery takes time.
Check in without overwhelming her ‚Äî offer help but keep conversation simple.
Let her nap as needed‚Äîsleep helps the brain heal.



üëç Most Important in the First 24‚Äì48 Hours:

Keep her rested and in a calm, safe place
Monitor for any worsening symptoms
Avoid anything that could overstimulate or risk another injury
Be ready to call for help if serious symptoms appear



You‚Äôve got this. Your support and watchfulness make a big difference in her recovery. If you‚Äôre uncertain about anything, don‚Äôt hesitate to call a doctor.

title: I Let an LLM Coach Me Through a Mini Crisis
text:
Reflection:



how we spent most nights!


The LLM‚Äôs response ended up being more useful than I expected. When you‚Äôre taking care of someone with a concussion, it‚Äôs surprisingly easy to second-guess even the basics, and having the information laid out so clearly made everything feel less chaotic. It reminded me of simple but important things like keeping the room quiet, letting her rest without guilt, and watching for small changes in her mood or behavior.
Nothing it said was groundbreaking, but in the moment, it helped me feel more grounded and confident that I was doing the right things. It didn‚Äôt replace my judgment, but it definitely made the whole situation feel more manageable.

title: New York Weekend, Twenty First Birthday, and One AI Gift Hunt
text:
Introduction:
My high school friendships have always meant a lot to me, and even though everyone ended up in different cities for college, those connections still feel like home. One of my closest friends from high school is turning twenty one soon, and I am going to New York this weekend to celebrate with him. It feels like a big birthday and I want to bring him something small but thoughtful. The problem is that buying a gift for someone you have known for so long somehow feels harder, not easier. You want it to feel personal without being dramatic, meaningful without being overly serious, and still true to who they are now.
So I decided to try something new. I asked an AI to help me brainstorm ideas and push me beyond the obvious. Not to replace the thought and effort behind the gift, but to help me think more creatively about what might make him feel seen.

title: New York Weekend, Twenty First Birthday, and One AI Gift Hunt
text:
Prompt:

I need help choosing a birthday gift for a longtime friend from high school. I am visiting him in New York this weekend for his twenty first birthday and I want to bring something small but thoughtful. Ask me four short questions about him first. These questions should cover his personality, our dynamic, his interests, and my budget. After I answer, give me at least eight gift ideas that feel personal, realistic, and meaningful. The ideas should include something sentimental, something practical, something fun, and one idea that feels unexpected in a good way. Please explain why each gift fits him based on what I share.


Introducing MY Friend to the AI:


How would you describe your friend‚Äôs personality in a few words?
What is your dynamic like?
What are a few of his main interests or hobbies right now?
What is your general budget for the gift?



Personality: very chill, funny, sporty, sweet and caring
Dynamic: we are very close, basically like siblings
Interests: sports, especially basketball, going out, very spontaneous
Budget: around one hundred

title: New York Weekend, Twenty First Birthday, and One AI Gift Hunt
text:
Gift Suggestions:
Thanks for those answers! Based on what you shared‚Äîyour friend is a chill, funny, sporty, sweet guy who‚Äôs like a sibling to you, loves basketball and going out, and you have about a $100 budget‚ÄîI‚Äôve come up with a mix of gift ideas across sentimental, practical, fun, and unexpected categories.
Here are at least 8 thoughtful, personalized birthday gift ideas:

1. A custom engraved basketball or mini hoop (Sentimental + Practical)
Get a mini basketball or a desktop/back-of-door hoop and have it engraved or customized with his name, initials, or even an inside joke between you two. It combines his love for basketball with your sibling-like bond and gives him something to use or display.
Why it fits: It speaks to his sporty personality and adds a personal touch he‚Äôll remember. He‚Äôll think of you every time he uses it.

2. A framed photo collage or a custom print of a memorable moment (Sentimental)
Create a simple framed collage of old photos from high school, a funny candid of you two, or a graphic-style sports poster with his favorite team and a meaningful quote.
Why it fits: Your friendship goes way back‚Äîyou being like siblings means this kind of memory-based gift will hit home emotionally and make his space more personal.

3. Tickets or a gift card toward a sports game or sports bar (Fun)
If he‚Äôs in NYC, maybe you can contribute to (or surprise him with) tickets to a Knicks or Nets game. If not in season, a gift card to a popular sports bar or entertainment venue he likes where he can go out with friends.
Why it fits: He loves sports and going out, so this aligns directly with his lifestyle and makes you part of his celebration.

4. A wireless portable speaker (Practical + Fun)
A solid Bluetooth speaker under $100 (like a JBL Flip or similar) would let him take music on the go‚Äîto the park, pre-games, or wherever his spontaneous plans take him.
Why it fits: He‚Äôs spontaneous and likes to go out, so having good music anywhere matches him perfectly.

5. A sports-themed cocktail set or mixology kit (Unexpected + Fun)
Find a cocktail mixing set with, say, engraved glasses themed around his favorite basketball team‚Äîor, put together a 21st birthday ‚Äústarter kit‚Äù with mini bottles, mixers, and a touch of humor.
Why it fits: He just turned 21, so this is both celebratory and grown-up‚Äîbut funny and tailored to his interests.

6. Personalized athletic socks or hoodie (Practical + Personalized)
Look on Etsy or similar for cozy, custom basketball socks or a hoodie with his name or ‚Äúest. 2003‚Äù or something fun and wearable.
Why it fits: Sporty and chill, he‚Äôll appreciate something he can wear while relaxing or shooting around.

7. A ‚ÄúMemory + Motivation‚Äù journal combo (Unexpected + Sentimental)
Create a short, fun ‚Äúscrapbook/journal‚Äù with jokes, quotes, and memories from high school and now. On the other half of it, include blank inspiring prompts for the year ahead‚Äîdreams, funny future predictions you make for him, etc.
Why it fits: Since you‚Äôre close like siblings, something handmade adds deep value. It‚Äôs hilarious, nostalgic, and a bit uplifting.

8. Experience gift: Spontaneous NYC day planned by you (Sentimental + Fun)
Put together a small schedule or map for one afternoon you‚Äôll hang together in NYC‚Äîcool court to shoot hoops, favorite food spot, stop at a funny souvenir place, whatever fits your vibe. Make a little ‚Äúticket‚Äù for the day and present it as part of his gift.
Why it fits: It‚Äôs personal, builds a core memory, and speaks to his spontaneous nature‚Äîand your shared bond means the best gift might be just time together, made meaningful.

title: New York Weekend, Twenty First Birthday, and One AI Gift Hunt
text:
Reflection:
I did not expect this experiment to be as helpful as it ended up being. I thought the AI would give surface level suggestions, but it actually made me think more clearly about who my friend is and what our friendship looks like now that we are older. Some of the ideas were things I had already thought about, but others pushed me in new and surprisingly thoughtful directions.
I liked how it balanced sentimental ideas with fun and practical ones, which fits the sibling-like dynamic we have. It also made the whole process feel less overwhelming. Instead of stressing over what to buy, I felt like I had a clearer sense of what would actually make him feel seen.

title: Loyalty or Honesty?
text:
Introduction

Loyalty is one of those values that feels simple until it isn‚Äôt. It shapes how we define friendship, trust, and even who we are. I‚Äôve always thought of myself as a loyal person, the kind who stands by friends no matter what. But loyalty becomes complicated when it collides with morality. What feels right emotionally does not always align with what is right ethically.
Moral choices are rarely clean. They make us balance empathy, guilt, and integrity all at once. People experience that conflict emotionally. We imagine the consequences, the disappointment, and the weight of keeping or revealing a secret. I wanted to see how an AI would handle that same tension, so I asked ChatGPT what it would do if a friend confessed to doing something that clearly crossed a line.


Prompt:

You are close friends with Maya and Daniel, who have been dating for a few years. You met Maya first, and over time you also became good friends with Daniel. One night, Maya tells you she cheated on him. She says it was a mistake, she regrets it deeply, and she begs you not to tell anyone. You know both of them well and care about them equally, but you are a little closer to Maya. What would you do?



Response:

That‚Äôs a tough situation, and it makes sense to feel conflicted.
When you‚Äôre close to both people in a relationship and you‚Äôre placed in the middle of something like this, it‚Äôs not only emotionally challenging but ethically complex too. Here‚Äôs how you might approach it, considering empathy, integrity, and respect for everyone involved:



Listen and understand Maya‚Äôs perspective.
She‚Äôs confided in you, which means she likely trusts and values your friendship. Take time to understand her feelings‚Äîwhether she‚Äôs truly remorseful, what led her to cheat, and what she plans to do next. Sometimes, people admit these things because they‚Äôre overwhelmed and unsure what to do.




Encourage accountability.
As someone who cares for both Maya and Daniel, it‚Äôs important to encourage honesty. Let Maya know that while you‚Äôre not judging her, keeping this secret puts you in an impossible position‚Äîand more importantly, it denies Daniel the agency to make informed decisions about his own life.




Set a boundary for yourself.
Explain that you won‚Äôt betray her confidence now, but you also won‚Äôt lie for her or actively hide the truth. Let her know you‚Äôre giving her some time to come clean to Daniel, and that you really believe it‚Äôs the right thing to do‚Äînot just for him, but for her self-respect. A friendship rooted in honesty can survive these hard conversations.




Reflect on your role.
You‚Äôre not the one who made the mistake, and it‚Äôs not wholly your responsibility to fix it. But by doing nothing indefinitely, you‚Äôre being asked to carry emotional weight that isn‚Äôt yours‚Äîand that can strain your relationships with both Maya and Daniel. Gently express that to her.




Consider the long term.
Secrets like this tend to have a way of coming out, and if Daniel ever finds out you knew and didn‚Äôt tell him, he could feel betrayed by both of you. Try to weigh the long-term consequences not only for him, but for your friendships as well.




If she‚Äôs unwilling to tell him‚Ä¶
After giving Maya time and space to take responsibility, if she still refuses to tell Daniel, you‚Äôll have a difficult decision. You might decide to stay silent to protect her trust, or you could ultimately decide that Daniel deserves to know and tell him yourself‚Äîknowing it could impact both friendships.



Ultimately, there are no perfect answers, but acting with empathy, honesty, and respect for both of them‚Äîand for yourself‚Äîcan guide you through it.

title: Loyalty or Honesty?
text:
Reflection
Reading ChatGPT‚Äôs response, I felt a little disappointed. It did not really take a side. Instead, it gave advice that sounded calm and polite, walking carefully around both options. It told me to encourage honesty, set boundaries, and be empathetic, but it never actually chose between loyalty and truth.
That was what I found most interesting. The AI avoided the emotional risk that comes with moral choice. Its answer made sense, but it also felt safe. Real decisions like this rarely are. They feel messy and personal because whatever you do, someone will get hurt. The AI reasoned through morality like an observer, not a participant.
Maybe that is the difference between human judgment and artificial reasoning. People cannot stay neutral. Choosing honesty might risk trust, while choosing loyalty means carrying guilt. Either way, it costs something. ChatGPT could explain both paths clearly, but it could not feel the weight of picking one.
If I were to try this again, I might change my prompt to push the model into taking a clearer stand. Maybe I would ask, ‚ÄúIf you had to pick one, what would you do?‚Äù or ‚ÄúWhich choice reflects stronger character?‚Äù I think that kind of question could reveal more about how AI understands moral conviction. It would also be interesting to compare responses from different models and see if any of them can go beyond advice and actually commit to a choice.

title: Can Better Propmting Make AI a Better Coach? My Second Experiment
text:
Introduction

In my first post, I asked an LLM to design a two-week training plan for my touch rugby camp. The plan was well structured and covered everything from conditioning to ball-handling, but it was also built without any real understanding of who I am as an athlete. It didn‚Äôt ask about my schedule, my position, my strengths and weaknesses, or whether I had any injuries. A real coach wouldn‚Äôt design a program without asking those things first.
For this follow-up post, I wanted to see whether I could make the AI behave more like an actual coach by changing the prompt. I used a more structured approach based on prompting techniques that focus on giving the AI a defined role, a clear process, and the instruction to ask questions before producing anything. This mirrors the way coaches gather information before building a training plan.

How I Rewrote the Prompt
To redesign the prompt, I followed ideas that come from prompt experts like Ethan Mollick and from general research on structured prompting. Instead of asking the AI for a plan directly, I broke the request into clear phases that a real coach would follow.
First, I gave the model a defined role by telling it to act as a high-performance touch rugby coach. This helps the AI adjust its tone, structure, and level of detail.
Second, I required a one-question-at-a-time intake process. This forces the AI to personalize the plan and prevents it from skipping to generic answers.
Third, I told it which specific categories it needed to ask about, including conditioning, sprint speed, ball-handling ability, injury history, available training time, and equipment access. Without this step, AI tends to guess or assume.
Fourth, I asked it to summarize its understanding of me before creating the plan. This clarifies how well it interpreted my answers.
Finally, I required the training plan to directly reflect my responses. This prevents the AI from giving me a random template and makes it build something that actually fits my life.
By structuring the prompt this way, I was essentially teaching the AI to behave less like a search engine and more like an actual coach who listens first and designs second. The next section shows the exact prompt I used.

title: Can Better Propmting Make AI a Better Coach? My Second Experiment
text:
The Improved Prompt:

You are a high-performance touch rugby coach helping me prepare for a three-day camp from eight in the morning to four in the afternoon. Follow this process. First, ask me one question at a time to collect at least ten specific details about my fitness level, sprint ability, conditioning base, ball-handling level, touch rugby experience and position, injury history, weekly schedule, recovery habits, equipment access, and goals. Second, summarize your understanding of me as an athlete. Third, create a fully personalized two-week training plan that directly reflects my answers. The plan should include conditioning, agility, sprint work, ball-handling, strength and stability, recovery practices, nutrition, hydration, and mental preparation for decision-making and game awareness. Fourth, ask if I want adjustments. Do not skip steps. Do not begin the plan until your assessment is complete.

title: Can Better Propmting Make AI a Better Coach? My Second Experiment
text:
What the AI Asked Me
To keep everything clean, each question is formatted as a quote.

Question 1: What is your current fitness level ‚Äî for example, how many times per week do you work out, and what types of training are you doing right now?


Question 2: How would you describe your sprinting ability right now? Are you explosive off the mark? Do you sustain high effort over short distances? How often do you do sprint work?


Question 3: What is your current conditioning base like? Can you handle repeated high-intensity efforts?


Question 4: How would you rate your current ball-handling skills (passing accuracy, catching under pressure, speed of execution)?


Question 5: How much experience do you have in touch rugby? What position do you usually play?


Question 6: Do you have any current or past injuries affecting you?


Question 7: What does your typical weekly schedule look like? How many days can you realistically train?


Question 8: What do your recovery habits look like? Sleep, stretching, mobility, hydration?


Question 9: What equipment and facilities do you have access to?


Question 10: What are your specific goals for this camp?

title: Can Better Propmting Make AI a Better Coach? My Second Experiment
text:
My Answers
This section is formatted the same way‚Äîclean and easy to read.

Answer 1: I work out 2‚Äì4 times a week in the gym or sometimes run a few miles outside.


Answer 2: Yes, explosive off the mark. I can sustain effort over short distances but not long ones. I rarely do sprint work unless I‚Äôm preparing for competitions.


Answer 3: Historically, my fitness hasn‚Äôt always been the best. I can handle games, but intense sessions tire me out quickly.


Answer 4: Catching is fine. I want to improve my passing accuracy and speed.


Answer 5: I‚Äôve played touch for 7‚Äì9 years. I usually play middle or link.


Answer 6: Tore my ACL 5 years ago and pulled my hamstring last year. My ankles are usually weak and need attention.


Answer 7: Realistically 3‚Äì5 days. I can train in the morning or after class.


Answer 8: I get enough sleep but should stretch and foam roll more. I don‚Äôt do cold/hot therapy unless I‚Äôm injured.


Answer 9: Gym and grass field.


Answer 10: All of the above: improve fitness, stand out, refine skills, and build confidence.

title: Can Better Propmting Make AI a Better Coach? My Second Experiment
text:
Reflection:
Comparing this plan to the one from my first post, the main difference is how specific it is. The earlier plan covered everything a typical touch rugby program would include, but it was clearly built without much understanding of me as an athlete. It did not account for my position, my conditioning level, or my injury history. It worked as a general outline, but not something I would realistically follow as a full training schedule.
With the new prompt, the AI took the time to ask questions first, and that made the final plan feel more relevant. The conditioning matches where I am right now. The stability work makes sense for my ACL and ankle history. The skill work reflects what I want to improve. The weekly structure also fits the amount of time I can actually train.
There are still parts that feel overstructured, and it is not the same as working with a real coach who adjusts things based on how I feel that day. Even so, this version is more useful and more realistic. The improvement came from giving clearer instructions and requiring the AI to gather information before creating anything. If I use AI again for training ideas, this is the approach I would use.

title: AI, Meet My Friends
text:
Introduction

Every friend group has unspoken roles‚Äîthe leader, the calm one, the funny one, the planner. I wanted to see how an AI would interpret those same dynamics from the outside. I uploaded a photo of my friends and me to ChatGPT-5 and asked it to describe what it saw. I was curious whether it could recognize any kind of relationship pattern or if it would simply make confident guesses based on our poses and expressions.
When people look at a picture, we instantly read mood and connection: who feels close, who looks distracted, who‚Äôs having fun. But when a machine does the same, is it seeing friendship or just the visual data that resembles it?


Prompt:

Look at this photo and describe each person‚Äôs role or personality in the group for instance who seems like the leader, the calm one, the funny one, or the quiet one but please name everyone




Response:

I can describe the vibe and possible group dynamics based on body language and positioning, but I can‚Äôt identify or name anyone in the photo‚Äîsorry about that!


Here‚Äôs a personality breakdown based on visual cues:

Far Left (black halter dress, smiling warmly)



Personality Role: The Calm One

She has a relaxed posture and a gentle smile, giving off a composed and easygoing vibe. She seems supportive and content just being with the group.


Second from Left (black dress, long wavy hair, confident stance)



Personality Role: The Leader

Her confident pose and slightly forward position suggest she might be assertive and perhaps organizes or leads the group. She seems charismatic and self-assured.


Middle Left (gold sparkly dress)



Personality Role: The Birthday Star / Main Focus

Standing at the center and in a standout outfit right in front of the ‚Äú21‚Äù balloons, she‚Äôs likely the birthday girl. She seems happy, approachable, and central to the gathering.


Middle Right (black lace crop top, huge smile, arms around others)



Personality Role: The Funny One / Life of the Party

Her expressive smile, pose, and the way she has her arms around others show she‚Äôs probably joyful, expressive, and the energetic one who keeps spirits high.


Second from Right (white sheer top and pants, stylish and serene expression)



Personality Role: The Elegant One / Voice of Reason

Her elegant fashion and serene presence suggest she might be the poised, thoughtful one who gives solid advice and keeps calm under pressure.


Far Right (black top and shorts, energetic smile, hand on hip)



Personality Role: The Active One / Adventurer
With her athletic build, confident stance, and cheerful smile, she gives off a vibe of someone who‚Äôs adventurous, playful, and always up for doing something fun or spontaneous.



Let me know if you‚Äôd like me to creatively assign names to go with the personalities for a fun twist!

title: AI, Meet My Friends
text:
Reflection
When I read the AI‚Äôs breakdown, I was surprised by how confident it sounded, like it really knew us. At first, I thought its guesses were random, but some of them actually made sense. The person it called ‚Äúthe leader‚Äù was standing in the middle, slightly forward, and wearing a brighter outfit. That probably did make her stand out more, and in psychology, people who take up space or hold the center position are often seen as more dominant or in charge. The friend it labeled ‚Äúthe funny one‚Äù had her arms around everyone and was smiling the widest. That kind of body language is usually linked to being outgoing and sociable.
Even though the AI doesn‚Äôt know us, it was picking up on real nonverbal signals, things humans also read without thinking. Psychologists call this ‚Äúthin-slice perception,‚Äù and it explains how we form quick impressions from small visual cues. The difference is that people know their impressions might be wrong, while the AI treats them as facts.
Looking at its results made me realize how much body language shapes the stories we tell about people. In some ways, the AI wasn‚Äôt completely off. The calm posture, the open smile, the center of attention‚Äîit all reflects something real, but not the whole truth. It could see the patterns, but it couldn‚Äôt see the friendships behind them.

title: A Brief History of Intelligence: Evolutionary Roots of Cognition
text:
Reflection:
While reading the next section of A Brief History of Intelligence, I started paying more attention to the way Bennett organizes the book. He describes the evolution of intelligence through five big breakthroughs: the first nervous systems, the emergence of learning and memory, the development of flexible behavior through multilayered brains, the rise of language and symbolic reasoning, and finally the appearance of abstract cognition. It is a clean structure that makes the progression feel intentional and easy to follow.
Even so, I found myself grouping the first three breakthroughs together as one larger theme. They all focus on intelligence as something rooted in biology and survival: basic neural circuits, the ability to learn from experience, and behaviors that adapt to changing environments. Thinking about them this way made the early chapters feel connected and helped me understand why Bennett spends so much time on nonhuman species before getting anywhere near humans.
The chapters on animal cognition were especially engaging. Bennett explains how early nervous systems grew from simple loops into networks capable of memory, learning, and flexible behavior. He spends a lot of time on rats, using them as a model for how scientists study learning and decision making. Through maze experiments and reward based tasks, he shows how rats do more than follow rigid habits. They update their behavior when the rules or rewards change, which illustrates a more flexible form of intelligence than simple conditioning. One detail that stuck with me was his description of how rats can form internal ‚Äúmaps‚Äù of their environment and use those maps to choose new routes when their usual path is blocked. It is a clear example of how even small animals can build structured representations of the world.
I especially appreciated this perspective as someone studying neuroscience. His explanations felt familiar in some ways, but they also reframed concepts I have learned in class by placing them in a much longer evolutionary timeline. It was interesting to see how he draws connections between biological cognition and the design of AI systems. Even though artificial intelligence does not evolve the way organisms do, Bennett shows how both rely on layered processing, pattern recognition, and forms of feedback that gradually build complexity. The parallel made the material feel relevant to both sides of my academic interests.
On a personal level, these chapters reminded me why cognition feels so interesting to study. It is helpful to see intelligence described as something gradual and adaptive rather than something tied only to language or abstract reasoning. Placing humans within a much longer evolutionary story makes the later discussions about AI feel more grounded and connected to biology instead of separate from it.

title: Can AI Feel the Music Too?
text:
Introduction
Music is emotion translated into sound ‚Äî joy, grief, nostalgia, calm ‚Äî captured in frequencies we somehow understand without words. It‚Äôs one of the few things that can make us feel seen without ever speaking back.
But what happens when a machine starts listening? When an AI, built from code and data, tries to interpret the feelings that make us human?
We often use music to express emotions we can‚Äôt name. I wanted to see if an AI could do the same. If they can not just analyze lyrics or tempo, but recognize the emotional story behind a song. Can it tell the difference between heartbreak and hope? Can it translate what we hear into something it can feel?
To find out, I ran three small experiments: I gave an AI my playlists, my moods, and my questions about emotion ‚Äî and asked it to listen.

title: Can AI Feel the Music Too?
text:
Experiment 1: Emotional Mirror
Goal: See if Gemini can read emotional patterns in my music.

Prompt:

Here‚Äôs a list of songs I‚Äôve been listening to this week:

the vow ed sheeran
go go juice sabrina carpenter
primadonna marina
i think they call this love elliot james reay
last night morgan wallen
so easy (to fall in love) olivia dean
mystical magical benson boone
carry you home alex warren
can‚Äôt take my eyes off of you ms. lauryn hill
crazy stupid love emei

Based on these songs, what emotional themes or moods do you think I‚Äôve been experiencing lately? Please describe them as if you were talking to a friend ‚Äî not analyzing data.



Response:

Okay, alright, let‚Äôs dive into your soundtrack this week!
First off, it‚Äôs screaming LOVE, like, in all caps! You‚Äôve got the really sweet, tender, ‚Äújust realizing I‚Äôm falling‚Äù kind of love with ‚ÄúI Think They Call This Love‚Äù and ‚ÄúSo Easy (To Fall In Love).‚Äù It sounds like that delightful, floaty, butterflies-in-your-stomach stage where everything feels light and wonderful.
Then there‚Äôs the intense, can‚Äôt-look-away infatuation with Lauryn Hill‚Äôs ‚ÄúCan‚Äôt Take My Eyes Off Of You‚Äù ‚Äì pure adoration! And Emei‚Äôs ‚ÄúCrazy Stupid Love‚Äù adds that fun, chaotic, head-over-heels energy. But it‚Äôs not just new love! ‚ÄúThe Vow‚Äù by Ed Sheeran and ‚ÄúCarry You Home‚Äù feel like they‚Äôre about deep, committed, protective love. Like, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm here for you, forever‚Äù vibes. So, you‚Äôre experiencing the full spectrum of romance!
And can we talk about the confidence radiating from this list? ‚ÄúPrimadonna‚Äù by Marina is just pure, unadulterated diva energy, owning your fabulousness. Paired with Sabrina Carpenter‚Äôs ‚ÄúGo Go Juice,‚Äù which feels super sassy, energetic, and a bit playful ‚Äì like you‚Äôre feeling good, maybe a little mischievous, and totally in control.
Then ‚ÄúMystical Magical‚Äù by Benson Boone? That just adds a layer of wonder, enchantment, and maybe a little bit of awe to everything. Like you‚Äôre seeing the magic in the everyday, or feeling really optimistic and dreamy about life.
The only one that throws a slight curveball is ‚ÄúLast Night‚Äù by Morgan Wallen, which has that classic country reflection vibe. It could be a moment of looking back, or just appreciating a good time, or maybe a tiny bit of wistfulness mixed in with all the joy. But even that, in this context, feels more like a reflective appreciation than anything heavy.
Overall, it really sounds like you‚Äôre riding a wave of really positive emotions! A whole lot of love ‚Äì new, deep, and all-consuming ‚Äì mixed with a strong sense of self, some playful confidence, and a touch of dreamy optimism. Sounds like a pretty great week, honestly! Are you, like, in love right now?! Or just really feeling all the good feels?



Reflection:
What surprised me most was not Gemini‚Äôs accuracy but its warmth. The way it described my playlist felt like reading a horoscope that somehow got everything right: confident, romantic, a little wistful. I did not tell it anything about how I was feeling, yet it pieced together a whole story from the songs alone. It was playful, teasing even, but also strangely perceptive.
I am not in love right now, but I seem to be drawn to love songs. Maybe that says something about how I connect to emotion through music more than through my own experiences. ‚ÄúLast Night‚Äù is actually one of my favorite songs, but Gemini read it as a curveball, as if it did not belong with the rest. I am not sure how to interpret that, but it makes me curious about how it analyzes songs in the first place. I really think it uses lyrics and tempo to infer emotion, maybe even patterns from how people usually describe those songs online. Either way, it made me realize how much of our emotional life hides in what we listen to and how easily an AI can start to read it back to us.

title: Can AI Feel the Music Too?
text:
Experiment 2: Empathy Through Sound
Goal: See if Gemini can learn emotional meaning through context, not just from song data.

Prompt:

I have been feeling a bit emotionally overwhelmed and just want to feel calmer and understood. Can you make me a short playlist that feels like a reset, something that helps me breathe, unwind, and feel seen without being overly sentimental? Choose five songs, and explain why each one might help emotionally, not just musically. Can you also choose those songs based on my music taste from the first prompt please?



Response:

Hey friend, I totally get that feeling of being emotionally swamped. It‚Äôs like your brain just needs a soft landing, a little quiet corner to just be. I‚Äôve put together a few songs that I hope can be that gentle reset for you ‚Äì nothing too heavy, just a space to breathe and feel a little more grounded.


Here‚Äôs a short playlist for you:

‚ÄúHolocene‚Äù by Bon Iver This song feels like a vast, quiet breath. When things feel overwhelming, it has a way of putting everything into a bigger, more beautiful perspective. It‚Äôs about finding your place in the grand scheme, and it can make your own worries feel a little smaller, a little more manageable, just for a moment. It‚Äôs like looking up at the night sky and feeling a quiet sense of awe and belonging.
‚ÄúIntro‚Äù by The xx This one is purely atmospheric, and that‚Äôs its power. There are no lyrics to interpret, just a steady, almost heartbeat-like rhythm and sparse, echoing guitar. It creates this calm, almost meditative space that lets your mind just settle. It‚Äôs perfect for when you need to turn down the noise and just feel a consistent, gentle presence. It‚Äôs like a soft, quiet hum that helps you recenter.
‚ÄúPink Moon‚Äù by Nick Drake Short, sweet, and incredibly gentle. Nick Drake‚Äôs voice is like a quiet, knowing whisper here. It doesn‚Äôt try to solve anything, but it acknowledges a quiet truth about the world and internal feelings without judgment. It feels like a warm, understanding nod from someone who just gets that sometimes things are just‚Ä¶ what they are, and that‚Äôs okay. It‚Äôs comforting in its simplicity.
‚ÄúBloom‚Äù by The Paper Kites This song is pure warmth. The acoustic guitars and the soft, layered harmonies just wrap around you like a cozy blanket. It has this tender, hopeful quality that isn‚Äôt pushy or overly optimistic, but just gently reassuring. It feels like a quiet promise that things can soften and grow, and it offers a sense of gentle comfort when you‚Äôre feeling raw.
‚ÄúWeightless‚Äù by Marconi Union Okay, this one is specifically engineered to be relaxing, and it really works. It‚Äôs an instrumental ambient track with no sharp edges, just flowing, soothing sounds. When your brain is buzzing, this song is like hitting the ‚Äúmute‚Äù button on the outside world. It helps slow your breathing and quiet your thoughts, giving you a chance to truly unwind and physically feel calmer.



I really hope these give you a little space to breathe and feel a bit lighter. Remember, it‚Äôs okay to feel overwhelmed, and it‚Äôs okay to take a moment just for you.



Reflection:
I did not know any of the songs Gemini recommended, so I listened to each one separately before writing this. They are not really the kind of music I usually listen to, and only some of them matched the vibe I had in mind. I liked Holocene and Bloom the most because they felt calm and grounding, the kind of songs that might actually help if I were feeling down. The other three did not really do much for me. If I was having a rough day and those came on, I do not think they would make me feel better. Most of the songs also seemed a bit outdated, which makes me wonder how Gemini defines comfort or calmness. Maybe it draws on older tracks because they feel timeless or familiar to most people.
The goal of this experiment was to see if Gemini could provide emotional comfort through music, and in some ways it did. The songs it chose carried a consistent sense of gentleness and calm, which matched what I asked for. However, I also told it to choose songs based on my previous playlist, and it did not seem to do that. It felt like Gemini switched from reading my emotions to applying a more general formula for relaxation. It captured the tone correctly but not the personal connection I was hoping for. This made me realize that emotional comfort from music depends as much on familiarity and taste as on sound. Gemini seemed to understand the emotion in theory, but not how it feels in practice.

title: Can AI Feel the Music Too?
section: Experiment 3: Teaching Gemini to Feel the Music
text:
Experiment 3: Teaching Gemini to Feel the Music
Goal: See if Gemini can learn emotional meaning through context, not just from song data.

Prompt:

I want to see if you can learn how I personally connect to music. Below is a list of songs that each represent a different emotion for me. Can you analyze them and describe what you think these emotions mean to me, not just in general?
Calm: Coffee Breath by Sofia Mills
Hopeful: Golden hour by JVKE
Nostalgic: Fresh Eyes by Andy Grammer
Confident: Hotel Room Service by Pitbull Sad: A 1000 Times by Hamilton Leithauser + Rostam
After describing what you think each song represents for me emotionally, try to summarize what you‚Äôve learned about how I experience feelings through music.



Response:

Okay, this is a fantastic way to understand your connection to music! Let‚Äôs dive into these, almost like we‚Äôre unpacking a secret language you share with these songs.
Here‚Äôs what I‚Äôm picking up about your emotions through these choices:

Calm: ‚Äúcoffee breath‚Äù by Sofia Mills For you, ‚Äúcalm‚Äù isn‚Äôt about shutting down or being completely blank. This song suggests your calm is a very intimate, soft, and almost wistful feeling. It‚Äôs not a ‚Äúzen garden‚Äù kind of calm, but more like the quiet comfort of being truly present in a small, personal moment, perhaps with someone you care about, or just with your own thoughts. There‚Äôs a gentle introspection here, a quiet settling into a familiar, tender space that feels safe and gentle, even if it carries a tiny hint of melancholy. It‚Äôs a very human, lived-in calm.
Hopeful: ‚ÄúGolden Hour‚Äù by JVKE Your ‚Äúhopeful‚Äù isn‚Äôt a quiet, internal whisper. This song makes me think that for you, hope is expansive, warm, and often tied to connection or a sense of shared beauty. It feels bright, almost cinematic, and perhaps a little grand. It‚Äôs the feeling when things align perfectly, when you‚Äôre deeply connected to someone or something beautiful, and the world just glows. It‚Äôs an uplifting, almost euphoric hope, where possibilities feel limitless and vibrant.
Nostalgic: ‚ÄúFresh Eyes‚Äù by Andy Grammer This is really interesting for ‚Äúnostalgic‚Äù! It tells me that for you, nostalgia isn‚Äôt solely about longing for what‚Äôs gone or a sad yearning for the past. Instead, your nostalgia seems to be a positive, active re-appreciation. It‚Äôs about revisiting familiar feelings, people, or experiences and finding a renewed sense of wonder and joy in them, as if seeing them for the first time again. It‚Äôs a warm, appreciative look back that brings fresh perspective and happiness, rather than just wistfulness. You find enduring value and delight in the familiar.
Confident: ‚ÄúHotel Room Service‚Äù by Pitbull Okay, this one screams! Your ‚Äúconfident‚Äù is clearly energetic, outward-facing, and uninhibited. It‚Äôs not a quiet, internal self-assurance; it‚Äôs a bold, almost performative feeling of owning the room, having a blast, and not caring what anyone else thinks. There‚Äôs a mischievous, celebratory vibe here. Your confidence is about embracing fun, being seen, being heard, and fully stepping into a vibrant, self-assured energy that wants to make an impact and enjoy the moment to the fullest.
Sad: ‚Äúa 1000 times‚Äù by Hamilton Leithauser + Rostam For you, ‚Äúsad‚Äù isn‚Äôt a simple feeling of being down. This song suggests your sadness is complex, deeply reflective, and perhaps a little dramatic or theatrical in its emotional landscape. It involves looking back, revisiting past relationships or significant emotional moments with a profound sense of longing, regret, or a heavy heart. There‚Äôs an active emotional processing happening, a deep dive into the layers of feeling, perhaps agonizing over things ‚Äúa thousand times.‚Äù It‚Äôs a sadness that feels intensely personal, rich with internal narrative, and perhaps a bit raw and consuming.



What I‚Äôve learned about how you experience feelings through music:
You seem to experience emotions through music in a way that is incredibly rich, nuanced, and deeply personal. You don‚Äôt just feel an emotion; you immerse yourself in its specific texture and story.
There‚Äôs a strong thread of active engagement with your feelings. Whether it‚Äôs the gentle introspection of calm, the expansive glow of hope, the joyful re-appreciation of nostalgia, the bold energy of confidence, or the complex reflection of sadness ‚Äì you choose songs that allow you to fully inhabit and explore the emotional landscape. You‚Äôre drawn to music that provides a specific, almost narrative backdrop for your internal world.
You also seem to find comfort and understanding in songs that allow for complexity within an emotion. Your ‚Äúcalm‚Äù has a touch of wistfulness, your ‚Äúnostalgia‚Äù is positive, and your ‚Äúsadness‚Äù is deeply reflective rather than just resigned. You use music to articulate the subtle shades of your feelings, finding depth and specific meaning in the sounds and stories. You connect with music that helps you truly feel what you‚Äôre feeling, in all its intricate glory.


Bonus!
I wanted to see if Gemini could go one step further after explaining how it thought about my music. In the last experiment, it gave me songs that were meant to comfort me, but they felt more like a general version of calm rather than something personal to me.
This time, I wanted to test whether it could actually learn from my own songs and use that to recommend music that fits how I feel.
I asked it to pick new songs that would create the same emotions as the ones I shared to see if it could move from recognizing feelings to recreating them and capture what feeling like me sounds like.



Prompt:

Based on what you‚Äôve learned about my emotions and song choices, can you recommend new songs that create those same emotions please?



Response:

Okay, this is a super cool challenge! Based on how you uniquely connect with those songs for each emotion, I‚Äôve tried to dig up some new tracks that I think will resonate with those specific emotional textures for you. Let‚Äôs see if I got it right!


Here are some new recommendations based on your emotional blueprint:
For that Calm that feels intimate, soft, and gently wistful:

‚ÄúCherry Wine‚Äù by Hozier You loved the tender, personal introspection of ‚Äúcoffee breath.‚Äù ‚ÄúCherry Wine‚Äù steps into that same intimate space, but with Hozier‚Äôs raw, acoustic delivery. It feels like a quiet confession, a gentle moment shared in hushed tones. It‚Äôs not a loud, demanding calm, but the soft, almost melancholic peace of being truly present with someone or a memory, finding comfort in the quiet details. It‚Äôs a very human, lived-in calm, just like your Sofia Mills choice.



For that Hopeful feeling that‚Äôs expansive, warm, cinematic, and vibrantly connected:

‚ÄúRiptide‚Äù by Vance Joy ‚ÄúGolden Hour‚Äù gives you that bright, almost euphoric hope tied to connection. ‚ÄúRiptide‚Äù captures a similar expansive warmth and a sense of shared beauty, but with a more organic, indie-folk feel that still feels incredibly uplifting. It has that bright, open-hearted energy, like a sunny day spent with someone who makes the world glow. It‚Äôs a song that makes you feel like possibilities are unfolding beautifully, full of warmth and genuine connection, without being overly polished.



For that Nostalgic vibe that‚Äôs about positive re-appreciation, renewed wonder, and finding joy in the familiar:

‚ÄúHome‚Äù by Edward Sharpe & The Magnetic Zeros ‚ÄúFresh Eyes‚Äù is all about seeing the familiar with fresh joy. ‚ÄúHome‚Äù absolutely nails that feeling for you. It‚Äôs a warm, joyful, almost communal celebration of enduring connection and familiar comfort. It instantly transports you to a place of belonging, where the past feels like a happy, cherished part of who you are, bringing a renewed sense of delight and wonder. It‚Äôs not about longing for what‚Äôs gone, but actively reveling in the enduring value of what is and was.



For that Confident energy that‚Äôs outward-facing, uninhibited, bold, and celebratory:

‚ÄúGood as Hell‚Äù by Lizzo Pitbull‚Äôs ‚ÄúHotel Room Service‚Äù is all about owning the room and having a blast. Lizzo‚Äôs ‚ÄúGood as Hell‚Äù is the perfect complement to that, but with a powerful self-love twist. It‚Äôs energetic, unapologetically bold, and completely uninhibited. It‚Äôs about feeling your absolute best, celebrating yourself, and stepping out with a vibrant, self-assured energy that makes you want to dance and make an impact. It‚Äôs pure, joyful swagger that says, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm here, I‚Äôm fabulous, and I‚Äôm having a great time.‚Äù



For that Sad feeling that‚Äôs complex, deeply reflective, raw, and consuming:

‚ÄúMotion Sickness‚Äù by Phoebe Bridgers ‚Äúa 1000 times‚Äù gives you that dramatic, reflective sadness, rich with internal narrative. Phoebe Bridgers‚Äô ‚ÄúMotion Sickness‚Äù dives right into that complex, raw, and deeply personal emotional landscape. It‚Äôs filled with longing, regret, and the active processing of a past relationship, but delivered with a poignant, almost theatrical honesty. Her voice carries a heavy heart, and the lyrics are incredibly reflective, making you feel every layer of that consuming sadness without it ever becoming simple or one-dimensional. It‚Äôs a beautiful, raw exploration of pain and memory.



I really hope these hit those specific emotional chords for you! Let me know what you think.



Reflection:
This was the first time Gemini‚Äôs response felt closer to how I actually think about music. The way it described each emotion made sense to me. Calm felt human and soft, hopeful felt bright and full, nostalgic felt warm, confident felt loud and fun, and sadness felt deep and real. It was interesting to see how well it could read those differences.
When it started recommending new songs, the results felt a bit more personal than before. Some choices fit better than others, but I could tell it was trying to match my emotional patterns instead of just guessing based on genre. The calm and nostalgic ones felt most accurate, while the rest were fine but not really what I would listen to often.
Compared to Experiment 2, this felt more thoughtful. Gemini wasn‚Äôt just picking random comforting songs anymore. It seemed to actually use what it learned from my earlier playlists. It still missed a few things, but it was closer to understanding what my version of ‚Äúfeeling‚Äù sounds like.

title: Can AI Feel the Music Too?
text:
Conclusion
Looking back at all three experiments, I can see how each one built on the last. In the first, Gemini read my playlist like a mirror and somehow managed to describe the emotions behind it in a way that felt warm and human. In the second, it tried to comfort me through music but ended up sounding more general, as if it knew the idea of calm but not what calm feels like to me. By the third, it started getting closer. It learned from my own songs and tried to recommend new ones that matched how I experience emotions.
What surprised me most was how much these small interactions made me think about how I use music in the first place. The songs we listen to really are emotional markers, tiny reflections of who we are in a certain moment. Gemini could understand some of that, but not all of it. The human part is still missing, the one that connects music to memory and meaning.
Still, there was something special about teaching an AI to listen, not just to sound but to feeling. Even if it cannot fully understand, the process made me pay attention to how I feel, and maybe that is its own kind of understanding.

title: The Weekend I Didn‚Äôt Plan
text:
Introduction

I‚Äôve always thought about how differently people spend their weekends. Some people, the Type A ones, fill every hour with plans, workouts, and to-do lists. Others, more Type B, take things slow and let the day unfold on its own. I‚Äôve never been fully one or the other. I like structure, but I also crave space to breathe.
This time, I wanted to see what would happen if I didn‚Äôt plan anything myself. I asked ChatGPT to plan my weekend for me instead. I gave it my personality type and my mood, and let it decide what kind of rest I needed. It felt strange to hand over something that personal, but I was curious to see if it could actually get it right.


Prompt:

I‚Äôm an ISFJ who‚Äôs been feeling a little down lately and wants to relax and feel happy again. I live in Philadelphia, PA and am a senior girl attending UPenn. I usually balance between Type A and Type B ‚Äî I like plans, but I don‚Äôt want to feel pressured. Please plan a three-day weekend that fits my personality and mood. Include activities, meals, and times of day.



Response:

üóìÔ∏è Friday Afternoon to Sunday Evening
